newsitem.title: TAIWAN: TAIWAN GOV'T SELLS 6.03 MLN SHARES IN CHINA STEEL.
newsitem.headline: TAIWAN GOV'T SELLS 6.03 MLN SHARES IN CHINA STEEL.

text.p: Taiwan's economics ministry on Wednesday auctioned off some 6.03 million shares in steel giant China Steel at a total value of T$187.533 million.

Wednesday was the third of a scheduled four-day auction during which the government planned to auction a total of 182.19 million shares in China Steel -- a sell-off that would reduce the state's stake in China Steel to 39.2 percent from 42.1 percent.
The shares were sold at an average price of T$31.1, the same as its Wednesday closing price, an official from the Taiwan Stock Exchange said by telephone.
The government began its sale of China Steel on Monday, auctioning off some 92.79 million shares for T$2.89 billion and some 30,000 shares for T$969,000 on Tuesday.
The remaining 83.34 million shares would be auctioned on Thursday, the official said.
The sell-off was part of a five-year process to sell the state's entire China Steel stake, officials have said.
China Steel, Taiwan's largest steel firm, was privatised in April 1995.
Taiwan's finance ministry last week auctioned some 418 million shares in Chiao Tung Bank -- a sell-off that reduced state's stake in the bank to 60.03 percent from 88.83 percent.
Taiwan's government said in January it planned to release some 800 million state-owned shares worth some T$100 billion in fiscal 1997/98 (July/June).

Taiwan said in July that the government's privatisation scheme would accelerate from the middle of 1998, outlining plans to release state-owned shares worth T$450 billion over the next three fiscal years.
